name: transport, freight, inland waterways, barge tanker | transport, freight, inland waterways, barge tanker | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2599/documentation

Based on "transport, freight, inland waterways, barge tanker RER 2000". Inventory refers to the entire transport life cycle. Port infrastructure expenditures and environmental interventions are allocated based the yearly throughput (0.04). Vessel manufacturing is allocated based on the total kilometric performance (867'000km) and its transport performance (1200/unit). For each transport activity 2 ports are required. The data of the energy use and combustion emissions represent the transport of good with a barge tanker with a carrying capacity not less than 50 tonnes operating on inland waterways.

Transport starting with the production of one barge tanker. Service of the energy use and combustion emissions starts with the consumption of fuel for propelling.

The module calls the modules addressing: production and maintenance of tanker; construction of port. In addition canal construction is called. The activity of energy use and combustion emisssions ends with the service of transporting 1 ton over a distance of 1 km. The dataset includes the consumption fo fuel, airborne gaseous emissions, particulate emissions, heay metal emissions and persistent organic compunds (POPs) emissions until and including the disposal of bilge oil.
category: H:Transportation and storage/50:Water transport/502:Inland water transport/5022:Inland freight water transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Extrapolated from "transport, freight, inland waterways, barge tanker RER 2000". Data from one port in Netherlands is employed as an estimate for international water transportation. Canal inventories represent one German canal. Data of the energy use and combustion emissions is representative for the European Rhine-Fleet.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: diesel engine technology. The data of the energy use and combustion emissions represent a barge tanker navigates in inland waterways (strecht of water, not part of the sea) and with the capacity of not less than 50 tonnes. The fuel used is exclusively diesel. Exhaust emissions from inland waterway vessels - predominately powered by diesel engines - are characterized by similar emission profiles as diesel engines of heavy duty vehicles. For heavy metal emissions are employed the same figures as for hevy-duty vehicle diesel engines.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: see geography This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description: EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description: Calculated value from Cl content in heavy fuel oil. Energy use and combustion emissions

flow.name: Hydrochloric acid
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value from sulphur content in diesel fuel. In Jungbluth (2003) a S-content of 0.05 M% for diesel is reported, resulting in an emission index of 1 g/kg SO2. Energy use and combustion emissions

flow.name: port facilities
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/429:Construction of other civil engineering projects/4290:Construction of other civil engineering projects

defaultProvider.name: market for port facilities | port facilities | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/429:Construction of other civil engineering projects/4290:Construction of other civil engineering projects

exchanges.description:
Calculate value; split results from PM split of diesel road vehicle exhaust emissions. Dorland (2000) as quoted in Bickel (2001) reported a PM10 emission index of 1 g/kg fuel which is employed in this project. It's employed the same size distribution as for heavy-duty vehicle diesel engines. Energy use and combustion emissions

Further references:
Bickel P. and Friedrich R. (2001) Environmental External Costs of Transport. Springer-Verlag Berlin and Heidelberg GmbH & Co. KG, Berlin - Germany

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Based in various literature values. The average fuel consumption is calculated by employing carrying capacity specific fuel consumption available from Dorland (2000) as quoted in Bickel (2001). The class specific fuel consumption is aggregated using the total carrying capacity of each class ZKR (2003) as allocation factor. Energy use and combustion emissions

Further references:
Dorland C. and Olsthoorn A. A. (2000) Inland shipping emission factors. Report for ExternE Core/Transport task 5.3, Amsterdam

Bickel P. and Friedrich R. (2001) Environmental External Costs of Transport. Springer-Verlag Berlin and Heidelberg GmbH & Co. KG, Berlin - Germany

ZKR (2003) Wirtschaftliche Entwicklung der Rheinschifffahrt 2000. Rhein und Binnenschifffahrtsstatistik. Download of June from mediaplan.ovh.net/~ccrzkr/Files/ra2001statde.pdf.

Borken J., Patyk A. and Reinhardt G. A. (1999) Basisdaten für ökologische Bilanzierungen: Einsatz von Nutzfahrzeugen in Transport, Landwirtschaft und Bergbau. Vieweg, Braunschweig/Wiesbaden

Bialonski W. (1990) Spezifischer Energieeinsatz im Verkehr - Ermittlung und Vergleich der spezifischen Energieverbräuche. Forschungsbericht FE Nr. 90 247/88, im Auftrag des Bundesministers für Verkehr (ausgeführt am Verkehrswissenschaftlichen Institut der Rheinisch-Westfälischen Technischen Hochschule Aachen), Bonn

exchanges.description:
Calculated value; standard basic uncertainty for heavy metals. In this project we use the same figures as we employed for heavy-duty vehicle diesel engines. Heavy metal emission indices of diesel fuels EEA (2000) and Jungbluth (2003) are applyed. Energy use and combustion emissions
